It's essential for genetic engineering when they want to produce recombinant DNA, especially in cases where you don't have the original template but need to create a specific sequence. So C seems plausible. D. Transcribe DNA from proteins. Hmm, reverse transcriptase doesn't do that. It converts RNA to DNA. That doesn't sound right because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) involves DNA polymerases recognizing specific primers and extending them. It's essential for genetic engineering when they want to produce recombinant DNA, especially in cases where you don't have the original template but need to create a specific sequence. So C seems plausible. D. Transcribe DNA from proteins. Hmm, reverse transcriptase doesn't do that. It converts RNA to DNA. If proteins were involved, maybe something else like an enzyme might be needed, but not reverse transcriptase. E. Convert lipids to DNA for genome mapping. That sounds unrelated.
